metadata.subject: chemistry
metadata.dotPoint: The reaction quotient (Q) as a quantitative measure of the extent of a chemical reaction: that is, the relative amounts of products and reactants present during a reaction at a given point in time

q_definition.name: Definition of Reaction Quotient
q_definition.correct: Q measures the ratio of product to reactant concentrations at ANY point during a reaction, not just at equilibrium.

ratio only at equilibrium.fix: Q can be calculated at ANY time. K is the special case when the system IS at equilibrium.
ratio only at equilibrium.action: Think: Q is a snapshot at any moment. K is the final destination.

rate of reaction.error: Q measures extent (how far), not rate (how fast).
rate of reaction.fix: Rate = change in concentration per time. Q = ratio of concentrations at one moment.
rate of reaction.action: Rate tells you speed. Q tells you position along the reaction path.

amount of products formed.error: Q is a RATIO, not an absolute amount.
amount of products formed.fix: Q compares products TO reactants. It's the ratio [products]/[reactants].
amount of products formed.action: A reaction can have lots of product but still have Q < K if there's even more reactant.

energy released.error: Q has nothing to do with energy.
energy released.fix: Q measures concentration ratios. Energy is measured by enthalpy (ΔH).
energy released.action: Q is about amounts, not energy. Don't confuse Q with thermodynamic quantities.

persistent.gap: You're confusing Q with other reaction properties.
persistent.action: Memorise: Q = concentration ratio at any time, K = concentration ratio at equilibrium only.

q_expression_structure.name: Structure of Q Expression
q_expression_structure.correct: Q has products in the numerator and reactants in the denominator, with concentrations raised to their stoichiometric coefficients.

reactants in numerator.fix: Products on top, reactants on bottom. Q = [products]/[reactants].
reactants in numerator.action: Memory trick: Products are the RESULT, and they go on TOP (numerator).

coefficients as multipliers.fix: For 2NO₂, write [NO₂]². The 2 is an exponent, not a multiplier.
coefficients as multipliers.action: Check: aA → [A]^a means coefficient a becomes the power.

no exponents used.error: Stoichiometric coefficients must appear as exponents.
no exponents used.fix: Every coefficient in the balanced equation becomes a power in the Q expression.
no exponents used.action: For N₂ + 3H₂ ⇌ 2NH₃: Q = [NH₃]²/([N₂][H₂]³). Note the powers.

adding concentrations.error: Q uses multiplication and division, not addition.
adding concentrations.fix: Q = [C]^c × [D]^d / ([A]^a × [B]^b). Products multiply in numerator, reactants multiply in denominator.
adding concentrations.action: Never add concentrations in equilibrium expressions. Always multiply.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how to construct Q expressions from equations.
persistent.action: Practice: write Q for 10 different balanced equations. Products up, reactants down, coefficients as powers.

q_units.name: Units of Q
q_units.correct: Q units depend on the specific reaction. They can be M, M², M⁻¹, or even unitless if products and reactants balance.

always M.error: Q doesn't always have units of M.
always M.fix: Units of Q = M^(sum of product coefficients − sum of reactant coefficients).
always M.action: For A ⇌ 2B: Q = [B]²/[A], units = M²/M = M. For A + B ⇌ C + D: unitless.

always unitless.error: Q is only unitless when coefficients balance perfectly.
always unitless.fix: If Σ(product coefficients) = Σ(reactant coefficients), Q is unitless. Otherwise, it has units.
always unitless.action: Check: N₂ + 3H₂ ⇌ 2NH₃. Products: 2, Reactants: 4. Units = M^(2−4) = M⁻².

units of mol/L/s.error: That's units for reaction rate, not Q.
units of mol/L/s.fix: Q has concentration units (M raised to powers). Rate has concentration per time units.
units of mol/L/s.action: Q measures position, not speed. No time in Q units.

units of kJ.error: kJ is energy. Q is a concentration ratio.
units of kJ.fix: Q has no energy units. It's purely a ratio of concentrations.
units of kJ.action: Don't mix up Q (reaction quotient) with q (heat energy in thermochemistry).

persistent.gap: You don't understand how stoichiometry determines Q units.
persistent.action: Calculate units for 5 different reactions by counting coefficients: products minus reactants gives the M exponent.

q_calculation.name: Calculating Q from Concentrations
q_calculation.correct: To calculate Q, substitute the actual concentrations at that moment into the Q expression and evaluate.

use initial concentrations only.error: Q can use ANY concentrations, not just initial ones.
use initial concentrations only.fix: Q is calculated from concentrations at the specific time you're measuring.
use initial concentrations only.action: If asked for Q at t=10s, use concentrations at t=10s, not t=0.

use equilibrium concentrations.error: Using equilibrium concentrations gives K, not Q.
use equilibrium concentrations.fix: Q uses current concentrations. K uses equilibrium concentrations. Q can equal K only at equilibrium.
use equilibrium concentrations.action: If they give you concentrations and say 'at equilibrium', that's K, not Q.

divide by time.error: Time is not part of the Q calculation.
divide by time.fix: Q = [products]/[reactants]. No time variable. Time tells you WHEN to measure concentrations.
divide by time.action: Time specifies the moment. Q uses only the concentrations at that moment.

subtract reactants from products.action: Equilibrium expressions always use ratios (division), never differences (subtraction).

persistent.gap: You're applying the wrong mathematical operation to calculate Q.
persistent.action: Practice substituting numbers into Q expressions for 10 different reactions.

k_definition.name: Equilibrium Constant Definition
k_definition.correct: K is the value of Q when the system has reached equilibrium. K is constant for a given reaction at a given temperature.

K changes during reaction.error: K is constant. Q changes during reaction.
K changes during reaction.fix: K is fixed for a reaction at a given temperature. Q varies as the reaction progresses toward K.
K changes during reaction.action: Think: K is the target, Q is your current position. Target doesn't move.

K equals rate constant.error: Equilibrium constant K ≠ rate constant k.
K equals rate constant.fix: K (capital) measures equilibrium position. k (lowercase) measures reaction rate.
K equals rate constant.action: Different symbols, different meanings: K = extent, k = rate.

K depends on concentration.fix: K depends only on temperature for a given reaction. Changing concentrations changes Q, not K.
K depends on concentration.action: Add more reactant: Q changes, but K stays the same. System shifts to restore Q = K.

K can be negative.fix: K = [products]/[reactants]. Concentrations are always positive, so K is always positive.
K can be negative.action: You can never have a negative concentration. Therefore Q and K are always ≥ 0.

persistent.gap: You're confusing K with rate constants or thinking K varies.
persistent.action: Remember: K is a CONSTANT for a reaction at fixed temperature. Only Q moves toward K.

q_less_than_k.name: Q < K Interpretation
q_less_than_k.correct: When Q < K, there are too few products relative to reactants. The forward reaction is favoured to increase Q toward K.

reverse reaction favoured.error: Opposite. Q < K means forward is favoured.
reverse reaction favoured.fix: Q < K means too few products. System needs MORE products → forward reaction.
reverse reaction favoured.action: Memory: Q < K, need to increase products. Forward makes products.

system is at equilibrium.error: At equilibrium, Q = K, not Q < K.
system is at equilibrium.fix: Q < K means not at equilibrium yet. System will shift forward.
system is at equilibrium.action: Equilibrium = Q equals K. If Q ≠ K, system is not at equilibrium.

reaction has stopped.error: Q < K means reaction is still proceeding.
reaction has stopped.fix: The reaction continues forward until Q = K. It hasn't stopped.
reaction has stopped.action: Q ≠ K means the system is changing. Only at Q = K does net change stop.

add more reactants.error: Q < K already means excess reactants relative to products.
add more reactants.fix: The system will naturally produce more products without adding anything.
add more reactants.action: Q < K = the system already has relatively more reactants. Forward shifts automatically.

persistent.gap: You don't understand what Q < K tells you about reaction direction.
persistent.action: Visualise Q on a number line approaching K. Q < K means Q must increase → more products → forward.

q_greater_than_k.name: Q > K Interpretation
q_greater_than_k.correct: When Q > K, there are too many products relative to reactants. The reverse reaction is favoured to decrease Q toward K.

forward reaction favoured.error: Opposite. Q > K means reverse is favoured.
forward reaction favoured.fix: Q > K means too many products. System needs FEWER products → reverse reaction.
forward reaction favoured.action: Memory: Q > K, need to decrease products. Reverse consumes products.

system is at equilibrium.error: At equilibrium, Q = K, not Q > K.
system is at equilibrium.fix: Q > K means not at equilibrium. System will shift reverse.
system is at equilibrium.action: Any time Q ≠ K, the system is out of equilibrium and will shift.

reaction will go to completion.error: Equilibrium reactions never go to completion.
reaction will go to completion.fix: The reaction shifts reverse until Q = K. Both directions continue at equilibrium.
reaction will go to completion.action: Reversible reactions reach equilibrium, not completion. Q approaches K.

no net change occurs.error: Net change occurs until Q = K.
no net change occurs.fix: Q > K means reverse is faster than forward. Net change produces more reactants.
no net change occurs.action: Only when Q = K does net change stop. Q > K means products are being consumed.

persistent.gap: You don't understand what Q > K tells you about reaction direction.
persistent.action: Visualise: Q > K means Q is too high. To reach K, Q must decrease → fewer products → reverse.

q_equals_k.name: Q = K Interpretation
q_equals_k.correct: When Q = K, the system is at equilibrium. The forward and reverse reaction rates are equal, and concentrations are constant.

reactions have stopped.error: At equilibrium, reactions continue but with equal rates.
reactions have stopped.fix: Dynamic equilibrium: forward and reverse rates are equal. Reactions don't stop.
reactions have stopped.action: Both reactions happen at equilibrium. Net change is zero, but activity continues.

concentrations are equal.error: Q = K doesn't mean all concentrations are equal.
concentrations are equal.fix: Q = K means the RATIO of products to reactants equals K. Individual concentrations vary.
concentrations are equal.action: K = 100 means products dominate. K = 0.01 means reactants dominate. Neither means equal.

forward rate is zero.error: Forward rate is NOT zero at equilibrium.
forward rate is zero.fix: At equilibrium, forward rate = reverse rate, and both are positive.
forward rate is zero.action: Dynamic equilibrium: constant activity, no NET change. Forward rate equals reverse rate.

reaction is complete.fix: Equilibrium means no NET change. Both reactants and products coexist.
reaction is complete.action: At equilibrium, you have both products AND reactants present. It's not complete.

persistent.action: Remember: equilibrium = constant macroscopic properties with ongoing microscopic activity.

temperature_effect_on_k.name: Temperature Effect on K
temperature_effect_on_k.correct: K is constant at a given temperature, but changes when temperature changes. The direction of change depends on whether the reaction is exothermic or endothermic.

K never changes.fix: K is constant at fixed temperature. Change temperature → K changes.
K never changes.action: Temperature is the ONE factor that changes K. Concentration changes only affect Q.

K changes with concentration.fix: Adding reactants changes Q. System shifts until Q = K again. K stays the same.
K changes with concentration.action: K is the target. Concentration changes move Q, not the target.

K changes with pressure.error: Pressure affects Q and equilibrium position, not K.
K changes with pressure.fix: Pressure changes shift the position, but K remains constant at constant temperature.
K changes with pressure.action: Only temperature changes the actual value of K for a reaction.

K changes with catalyst.fix: Catalysts speed up BOTH forward and reverse equally. K is unchanged.
K changes with catalyst.action: Catalysts affect rate, not equilibrium position or K value.

persistent.gap: You don't understand that only temperature affects K.
persistent.action: Memorise: Temperature → K changes. Concentration, pressure, catalyst → only Q changes or rate changes.

extent_meaning.name: Extent of Reaction
extent_meaning.formula: Q measures extent at any time
extent_meaning.correct: Extent refers to how far the reaction has progressed toward products. Q quantifies this by comparing product to reactant concentrations.

how fast the reaction occurs.fix: Extent = how far (position). Rate = how fast (speed).
how fast the reaction occurs.action: Extent is like distance travelled. Rate is like speed. Different concepts.

total amount of substance.error: Extent is a relative measure, not absolute.
total amount of substance.fix: Extent compares products to reactants. It's about the ratio, not total amounts.
total amount of substance.action: A reaction can have large extent with small amounts (if products >> reactants).

energy released.error: Energy is thermodynamics, extent is about concentrations.
energy released.fix: Extent is measured by Q (concentration ratio). Energy is measured by ΔH.
energy released.action: Extent = where you are along the reaction coordinate. Energy = how much heat released.

time taken.error: Time relates to rate, not extent.
time taken.fix: Extent is position at a given moment. Time tells you when, not how far.
time taken.action: You can have large extent quickly (fast reaction) or slowly (slow reaction).

persistent.gap: You're confusing extent with rate or other reaction properties.
persistent.action: Think of extent as position on a journey. Rate is speed. Q measures your current position.

crocodile_rule.name: Q vs K Direction Rule
crocodile_rule.formula: Q < K → forward, Q > K → reverse
crocodile_rule.correct: Compare Q to K: if Q < K, forward is favoured. If Q > K, reverse is favoured. The system shifts to make Q approach K.

Q < K means reverse.fix: Q < K: too few products, need more → forward reaction. Remember: Q follows K.
Q < K means reverse.action: Use the crocodile: < points right (forward), > points left (reverse).

Q > K means forward.fix: Q > K: too many products, need fewer → reverse reaction.
Q > K means forward.action: Q must decrease toward K. Reverse reaction decreases Q by consuming products.

compare K to Q instead.error: Always write Q first for the rule to work.
compare K to Q instead.fix: Q < K (Q comes first). If you flip it (K > Q), interpretation reverses.
compare K to Q instead.action: Standardise: always ask 'is Q less than or greater than K?'

direction depends on coefficients.error: Direction depends on Q vs K comparison, not stoichiometry.
direction depends on coefficients.fix: Stoichiometry affects the Q expression. Direction is determined by comparing Q to K.
direction depends on coefficients.action: Coefficients go into writing Q. Comparing Q to K tells you direction.

persistent.gap: You're getting the Q vs K comparison backwards.
persistent.action: Draw the crocodile eating toward K. Q < K → mouth points right → forward. Q > K → mouth points left → reverse.

q_definition.title: Understanding the Reaction Quotient
q_definition.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of Q.

sentences.text: The reaction quotient, Q, is a {{d1}} measure of the extent of a chemical reaction, representing the relative amounts of {{d2}} and {{d3}} present at a given point in time.

d1.tooltip: Q gives a specific numerical value, not just a description

d2.tooltip: Q compares what the reaction produces to what it starts with

d3.tooltip: These are the starting materials that get used up

sentences.text: Unlike the equilibrium constant K, the reaction quotient Q can be calculated at {{d4}} during a reaction, not just when the system has reached {{d5}}.

d4.tooltip: Q is a snapshot that can be taken whenever you want

d5.tooltip: This is the state where forward and reverse rates are equal

sentences.text: The value of Q changes as a reaction proceeds because the {{d6}} of reactants and products change over time until the system reaches {{d7}}.

d6.tooltip: Q is calculated using these values in mol/L

d7.tooltip: At this point, Q becomes constant and equals K

q_expression.title: Writing Q Expressions
q_expression.instructions: Complete the dropdowns about how to construct Q expressions.

sentences.text: For the general reaction aA + bB ⇌ cC + dD, the reaction quotient expression has {{d1}} concentrations in the numerator and {{d2}} concentrations in the denominator.

d1.tooltip: What the reaction makes goes on top

d2.tooltip: What the reaction uses up goes on the bottom

sentences.text: In the Q expression, stoichiometric coefficients from the balanced equation become {{d3}} on the concentration terms, so [C]^c means the concentration of C raised to the power of {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: Coefficients become powers, not multiplication factors

d4.tooltip: The coefficient in the balanced equation determines this

sentences.text: For the reaction N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g), the Q expression is Q = [NH₃]²/([N₂]{{d5}}), where the exponent on [H₂] is {{d6}} because that is the coefficient in the balanced equation.

d6.tooltip: Look at the coefficient in front of H₂ in the equation

sentences.text: The units of Q depend on the {{d7}} of the reaction. If there are more moles of products than reactants, Q will have units of {{d8}}.

d7.tooltip: The coefficients in the balanced equation determine units

d8.correct: M (or M raised to a power)
d8.tooltip: Q is based on concentration ratios, which have molarity units

q_vs_k.title: Comparing Q and K
q_vs_k.instructions: Complete the dropdowns about the relationship between Q and K.

sentences.text: The equilibrium constant K is the value of Q when the system has reached {{d1}}. At this point, the forward and reverse reaction rates are {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: K is specifically the Q value at this special state

d2.tooltip: This is the defining characteristic of dynamic equilibrium

sentences.text: While Q can change as concentrations change during a reaction, K remains {{d3}} as long as {{d4}} is held constant.

d3.tooltip: K is an equilibrium CONSTANT for good reason

d4.tooltip: This is the only factor that changes K

sentences.text: Adding a catalyst to a reaction at equilibrium will {{d5}} K because catalysts affect the {{d6}} of both forward and reverse reactions equally.

d5.tooltip: Catalysts speed up reactions but don't change equilibrium position

d6.tooltip: Catalysts make reactions faster, not more complete

predicting_direction.title: Using Q to Predict Reaction Direction
predicting_direction.instructions: Complete the dropdowns about predicting which direction a reaction will shift.

sentences.text: When Q < K, there are relatively {{d1}} products compared to what is needed for equilibrium, so the {{d2}} reaction is favoured.

d1.tooltip: Q is small because products are in the numerator

d2.tooltip: The system needs to make more products to reach K

sentences.text: When Q > K, there are relatively {{d3}} products compared to equilibrium, so the {{d4}} reaction is favoured to consume products.

d3.tooltip: Q is large because products (numerator) are high

d4.tooltip: The system needs to reduce products to reach K

sentences.text: When Q = K, the system is at {{d5}} and there is no {{d6}} change in concentrations because the forward and reverse rates are equal.

d5.tooltip: This is the only state where Q equals K

d6.tooltip: Reactions still occur, but forward and reverse cancel out

sentences.text: The reaction quotient Q provides a measure of the {{d7}} of a reaction, telling us how far the reaction has proceeded toward forming {{d8}}.

d8.tooltip: A larger Q means more products relative to reactants

q_definition.title: Applying the Reaction Quotient Concept
q_definition.instructions: Apply your understanding of Q to these scenarios.

sentences.text: A chemist measures concentrations partway through a reaction and calculates Q = 0.5. If K = 2.0 for this reaction, the system is {{d1}} equilibrium and the forward reaction will be {{d2}} to increase the product concentration.

d1.tooltip: Q ≠ K means the system is not at equilibrium

d2.tooltip: Q < K means more products are needed

sentences.text: In the reaction 2SO₂(g) + O₂(g) ⇌ 2SO₃(g), if [SO₃] = 0.1 M, [SO₂] = 0.2 M, and [O₂] = 0.1 M, then Q = [SO₃]²/([SO₂]²[O₂]) = {{d3}}.
When a reaction begins with only reactants and no products, Q initially equals {{d4}}. As the reaction proceeds forward, Q will {{d5}} until it equals K.

d4.tooltip: With no products, the numerator of Q is zero

d5.tooltip: As products form, Q increases toward K

q_expression.title: Constructing and Using Q Expressions
q_expression.instructions: Apply your knowledge of Q expressions to these problems.

sentences.text: For the decomposition reaction 2N₂O₅(g) ⇌ 4NO₂(g) + O₂(g), the Q expression has {{d1}} concentration terms in the numerator and {{d2}} concentration term(s) in the denominator.

d1.tooltip: Count the product species: NO₂ and O₂

d2.tooltip: Count the reactant species: only N₂O₅

sentences.text: For the reaction PCl₅(g) ⇌ PCl₃(g) + Cl₂(g), the Q expression is Q = {{d3}}/[PCl₅]. Since there are 2 moles of gaseous products and 1 mole of gaseous reactant, the units of Q are {{d4}}.

d4.tooltip: 2 product moles − 1 reactant mole = exponent of 1 on M

sentences.text: In the Haber process, N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g), if all concentrations are 1.0 M, then Q = {{d5}}. Since K = 0.5 at a certain temperature, the {{d6}} reaction is favoured.

d6.tooltip: Q (1.0) > K (0.5), so reverse is favoured

q_vs_k.title: The Relationship Between Q and K in Practice
q_vs_k.instructions: Apply your understanding of Q vs K to these scenarios.

sentences.text: If an exothermic reaction at equilibrium is heated, K will {{d1}} because the equilibrium shifts to favour the {{d2}} reaction, which absorbs the added heat.

d2.tooltip: The reverse of an exothermic reaction is endothermic

sentences.text: When a system at equilibrium is disturbed by adding more reactant, Q immediately {{d3}} because the denominator of the Q expression increases. The system then shifts {{d4}} to restore equilibrium.

d3.tooltip: Larger denominator means smaller Q value

sentences.text: The value of K for a reaction is 4.0 × 10⁻³ at 25°C. This small K value indicates that at equilibrium, the concentration of {{d5}} is much greater than the concentration of {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Small K means small numerator (products) relative to denominator (reactants)

d6.tooltip: K << 1 means products are present in small amounts

predicting_direction.title: Predicting Equilibrium Shifts Using Q
predicting_direction.instructions: Use Q to predict how systems will respond to changes.

sentences.text: A reaction has K = 10. If at a certain moment Q = 100, then Q {{d1}} K, and the system will shift to produce more {{d2}} until Q decreases to equal K.

d2.tooltip: Reverse reaction converts products back to reactants

sentences.text: If products are removed from a system at equilibrium, Q will {{d3}} because the numerator of Q decreases. The system responds by shifting {{d4}} to produce more products.

d4.tooltip: Q < K triggers forward reaction to make more products

sentences.text: The 'crocodile rule' states that if Q < K, the reaction proceeds in the {{d5}} direction, like following an arrow pointing {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: The < symbol opens toward K, pointing right (forward)

d6.tooltip: Forward reactions are conventionally written left to right

q_definition.title: Mastering Reaction Quotient Concepts
q_definition.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of Q by addressing common misconceptions.

sentences.text: A student claims that Q tells us how fast a reaction occurs. This is {{d1}} because Q measures the {{d2}} of a reaction (how far it has progressed), not the rate (how quickly it progresses).

d1.tooltip: Q and rate are different concepts

sentences.text: Another student believes Q can only be calculated at equilibrium. This is {{d3}} because Q can be calculated at {{d4}}, while K is the specific value of Q only at equilibrium.

d3.tooltip: Q is more general than K

d4.tooltip: Q is a snapshot at any moment

sentences.text: When comparing Q and K, a student states 'Q = K means the reaction has stopped.' This statement is {{d5}} because at equilibrium, both forward and reverse reactions continue at {{d6}} rates.

q_expression.title: Advanced Q Expression Analysis
q_expression.instructions: Apply your understanding to complex Q expression problems.

sentences.text: For the reaction 2A(g) + B(g) ⇌ 3C(g), if [A] = 0.2 M, [B] = 0.1 M, and [C] = 0.3 M, then Q = [C]³/([A]²[B]) = {{d1}}. The units are {{d2}} because there are 3 moles of products and 3 moles of reactants.
A student writes Q = [A][B]/[C][D] for the reaction A + B ⇌ C + D. This is {{d3}} because products should be in the {{d4}} and reactants in the {{d5}}.
For a reaction where Q has units of M², doubling all concentrations would {{d6}} the value of Q by a factor of {{d7}}.

d6.tooltip: M² means products have 2 more moles than reactants

d7.tooltip: If Q ∝ M², then doubling M gives Q × 2² = 4Q

q_vs_k.title: Q and K in Complex Scenarios
q_vs_k.instructions: Apply Q vs K understanding to challenging situations.

sentences.text: A reaction has K = 1.0 × 10⁶. This very large K indicates the equilibrium lies far to the {{d1}}, meaning at equilibrium there will be {{d2}} products than reactants.

d1.tooltip: Large K means products dominate at equilibrium

sentences.text: If you reverse a chemical equation, the new equilibrium constant K' is related to the original K by K' = {{d3}}. Similarly, the new Q' = {{d4}}.
Adding an inert gas at constant volume to a gaseous equilibrium will {{d5}} affect K and will {{d6}} affect Q because the concentrations of reactive species are unchanged.

d6.tooltip: Q depends only on reactive species concentrations

predicting_direction.title: Advanced Prediction Using Q
predicting_direction.instructions: Use Q to make sophisticated predictions about reaction behaviour.

sentences.text: For the reaction CO(g) + 2H₂(g) ⇌ CH₃OH(g), if K = 10 and the current concentrations give Q = 10, then the net rate of the forward reaction is {{d1}} the net rate of the reverse reaction.

d1.tooltip: Q = K means equilibrium, so rates are equal

sentences.text: A system has Q = 0.001 and K = 0.001. To shift this equilibrium toward products, you could {{d2}} the temperature if the forward reaction is {{d3}}.

d3.tooltip: Heat favours the reaction that absorbs heat

sentences.text: If a reaction mixture has Q = 5 and K = 50, the system needs to produce {{d4}} products to reach equilibrium. The forward reaction will be favoured until Q {{d5}} to equal K.

d4.tooltip: Q < K means too few products

d5.tooltip: Forward reaction increases products, increasing Q

sentences.text: The reaction quotient Q provides a {{d6}} for comparing the current state of a reaction to its equilibrium state. When Q ≠ K, the system is {{d7}} and will shift until Q = K.

d6.tooltip: Q gives a specific number to compare with K

q_definition.title: The Reaction Quotient (Q)
q_definition.content: The reaction quotient Q is a quantitative measure of the relative amounts of products and reactants present in a reaction mixture at any given point in time. Unlike K, which is only measured at equilibrium, Q can be calculated at any moment during a reaction.
keyPoints: Q can be calculated at any time, not just at equilibrium
Q changes as the reaction progresses
When Q = K, the system is at equilibrium

q_expression_structure.title: Writing Q Expressions
q_expression_structure.content: For any reaction aA + bB ⇌ cC + dD, the reaction quotient is Q = [C]^c[D]^d / [A]^a[B]^b. Products appear in the numerator and reactants in the denominator, with stoichiometric coefficients becoming exponents.
keyPoints: Products in numerator, reactants in denominator
Only include species in solution or gaseous phase

q_units.title: Units of Q and K
q_units.content: The units of Q (and K) depend on the stoichiometry of the reaction. Calculate the net change in moles: (sum of product coefficients) − (sum of reactant coefficients). This gives the power on M for the units.
keyPoints: Units depend on the specific reaction
Can be M, M², M⁻¹, or unitless
Unitless when total moles of products = total moles of reactants

q_calculation.title: Calculating Q
q_calculation.content: To calculate Q, substitute the actual concentrations at that specific moment into the Q expression and evaluate. The concentrations used are those present at the time of measurement, not initial or equilibrium concentrations.
keyPoints: Use concentrations at the specific time point
Substitute directly into the Q expression
Q can be calculated at any time during the reaction

k_definition.title: The Equilibrium Constant (K)
k_definition.content: K is the value of Q when a system has reached equilibrium. K is constant for a given reaction at a given temperature. Changing temperature changes K, but changing concentration, pressure, or adding a catalyst does not change K.
keyPoints: K is constant at constant temperature
Large K means products favoured; small K means reactants favoured

q_less_than_k.title: When Q < K
q_less_than_k.content: When Q < K, there are relatively too few products compared to what is needed for equilibrium. The forward reaction is favoured, producing more products and consuming reactants, until Q increases to equal K.
keyPoints: Q < K means too few products

q_greater_than_k.title: When Q > K
q_greater_than_k.content: When Q > K, there are relatively too many products compared to equilibrium. The reverse reaction is favoured, consuming products and regenerating reactants, until Q decreases to equal K.
keyPoints: Q > K means too many products

q_equals_k.title: When Q = K (Equilibrium)
q_equals_k.content: When Q = K, the system is at equilibrium. The forward and reverse reaction rates are equal, and there is no net change in concentrations. This is dynamic equilibrium—reactions continue, but the rates balance.

temperature_effect_on_k.title: What Affects K?
temperature_effect_on_k.content: K is affected only by temperature. For exothermic reactions, increasing temperature decreases K. For endothermic reactions, increasing temperature increases K. Concentration, pressure, volume, and catalysts do not change K.
keyPoints: Catalysts, concentration, pressure do NOT change K

extent_meaning.title: Extent of Reaction
extent_meaning.content: Extent refers to how far a reaction has progressed toward forming products. Q quantifies extent by comparing product concentrations to reactant concentrations. Extent is different from rate (how fast) or energy (how much released).
keyPoints: Extent = how far the reaction has progressed
Q measures extent at any given time

crocodile_rule.title: The Q vs K Direction Rule
crocodile_rule.content: To predict reaction direction, compare Q to K. If Q < K, the forward reaction is favoured (Q must increase). If Q > K, the reverse reaction is favoured (Q must decrease). The 'crocodile rule' uses the < and > symbols as arrows pointing toward the direction of shift.
keyPoints: Q = K → at equilibrium (no net shift)
Always write Q first when comparing
